name: jelly
content:
jelly noun
(SUBSTANCE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
A2 [ C or U ] a sweet soft food made by cooking fruit with sugar to preserve it. It is smooth, without any pieces of fruit in it. Jelly is eaten on bread: a peanut butter and jelly sandwich apple jelly Compare
jam noun (FOOD)
marmalade
istetiana/Moment/GettyImages
[ C or U ] UK (US trademark Jell-O) a soft, sweet, usually brightly coloured food made from sugar, gelatine, and fruit flavours, that shakes slightly when it is moved: I've made a strawberry jelly for the children's tea. jelly and ice cream
Edith64/iStock/Getty Images Plus/GettyImages
[ U ] any soft, slightly wet substance that shakes slightly when it is moved: Frogs' eggs are covered in a sort of transparent jelly.
More examplesFewer examplesLeave the jelly in the fridge to set.I was shaking like a jelly before my exam.Add a spoonful of redcurrant jelly to the sauce.The jelly mould was shaped like a crown.The contents of the bag had turned into an amorphous mass of jelly.

jellies
[ plural ] (also jelly shoes) shoes made from coloured transparent plastic, worn especially at the beach: Are jellies comfortable?
See more
jelly noun
(CREATURE)
US a jellyfish (= a sea creature with a soft, oval, almost transparent body): Jellies are usually densest in the ocean south of Winyah Bay. With the numbers of jellies booming, more swimmers are getting stung.

Add to word list
a soft, sweet, slightly solid food made by boiling fruit juice with sugar: grape/apple jelly a peanut butter and jelly sandwich
Jelly is also a substance that is almost solid: petroleum jelly
